steps.title: Pour the water and add the sugar to the large saucepan.
steps.content: Pour the water and add the sugar to the large saucepan.

steps.title: Place the pan over low to medium heat.
steps.content: Place the pan over low to medium heat. Stir until the sugar dissolves completely. Once dissolved, stop stirring.

steps.title: Clean the edges of the pan.
steps.content: Clean the edges of the pan. Use a small pastry brush dampened with water and brush down the edges of the pan.

steps.title: Bring the liquid to a boil.
steps.content: Bring the liquid to a boil. Then add either the glucose or the cream of tartar. Stir immediately.

steps.title: Continue stirring the boiling syrup.
steps.content: Continue stirring the boiling syrup. Test for readiness in one of the two following ways: Either take a teaspoonful and drop the syrup onto a saucer. If it forms a soft ball, it's ready. If not, keep boiling and test again shortly. Place a candy thermometer into the syrup. If it registers 240ºF/115ºC, it's ready.

steps.title: Remove from the heat source immediately.
steps.content: Remove from the heat source immediately. Let stand until the air bubbles stop forming.

steps.title: Pour the syrup into a large wet deep plate or basin or onto a marble slab with candy bar edges to prevent it from running over the sides.
steps.content: Pour the syrup into a large wet deep plate or basin or onto a marble slab with candy bar edges to prevent it from running over the sides. Ensure that the depth of the syrup is no greater than 1 1/2 inches/3.8cm.

steps.title: Allow to set.
steps.content: Allow to set. It will need to be cool enough to handle.

steps.title: Use a wooden spoon or butter paddle to cream the cooled fondant.
steps.content: Use a wooden spoon or butter paddle to cream the cooled fondant. Move it back and forth with the implement and your fingers.

steps.title: Knead all of the fondant.
steps.content: Knead all of the fondant. The aim is for it to turn white and no longer clear. It should be free of lumps and smooth.

steps.title: Cure the fondant coating.
steps.content: Cure the fondant coating. After the fondant turns smooth and white, place a dampened clean cloth or tea towel over it. Set aside to sit under this dampened cloth for 1 hour. It can remain longer if wished but 1 hour is the minimum.

steps.title: Knead again after the hour has passed.
steps.content: Knead again after the hour has passed.

steps.title: Lay wax paper out on a plate or baking sheet.
steps.content: Lay wax paper out on a plate or baking sheet. This will form the resting place for the dipped almonds. If making a lot of covered almonds, you'll need more than one plate or baking sheet; use your judgment.

steps.title: Melt the fondant in a saucepan.
steps.content: Melt the fondant in a saucepan.

steps.title: Dip the blanched almonds into the melted mass one by one.
steps.content: Dip the blanched almonds into the melted mass one by one. Pick them out with a fork. As you bring up each almond, tap gently against the side of the pan and wipe off any excess fondant.

steps.title: Place each dipped almond onto the wax paper.
steps.content: Place each dipped almond onto the wax paper. Leave for 5 minutes, then turn over to dry and harden on the other side.

steps.title: Done.
steps.content: Done. These can now be used as wedding favors or for treats. To present at a wedding, use either favor boxes or gauze bags tied with ribbon.
